photo.title: Paris : Fontaine du Palmier

photo.description: La Fontaine du Palmier (Palm Tree Fountain), constructed in 1806 to 1808 by François-Jean Bralle (1750-1832) to celebrate French victories in battle. It has a circular basin, six metres (twenty feet) in diameter, from which a column rises in the form of a palm tree's trunk 18 metres (58 feet) tall. The palm trunk is surmounted by a gilded figure of the goddess, Victory, holding a laurel wreath in each upraised hand; the goddess figure stands on a base ornamented with bas-relief eagles. Four allegorical figures by Louis-Simon Boizot (1743-1809) ring the base of the fountain: Prudence, Temperance, Justice, and Strength. From top to bottom, bands of bronze gilt pay tribute to the victories achieved in the following battles: The Siege of Danzig (1807, Prussia), the Battle of Ulm (1805, Austria), the Battle of Marengo (1800, Italy), the Battle of the Pyramids (1798, Egypt), and the Battle of Lodi (1796, Italy). Its sphinxes were designed in 1858 by Gabriel Davioud and sculpted by Henri Alfred Jacquemart (1824-1896); they commemorate Napoleon's victory in Egypt.

photo.title: Palm Tree Victory Column, Pt. 2

photo.title: Paris : Fontaine du Palmier

photo.description: The fountain, found in the Place du Châtelet, has palm leaves at the top, and is guarded by sphinxes; it was designed to commemorate the Egyptian Camptaign of Napoleon I. The fountain was built between 1806-08, designed by François-Jean Bralle (1750–1832). The fountain was one of fifteen built to provide drinking water to the citizens of public. The statue on top of the column is of Victory by sculptor Louis-Simon Boizot (1743–1809); the sphinxes were sculpted by Henri Alfred Marie Jacquemart (1824-96).

photo.description: La Fontaine du Palmier (Palm Tree Fountain), constructed in 1806 to 1808 by François-Jean Bralle (1750-1832) to celebrate French victories in battle. It has a circular basin, six metres (twenty feet) in diameter, from which a column rises in the form of a palm tree's trunk 18 metres (58 feet) tall. The palm trunk is surmounted by a gilded figure of the goddess, Victory, holding a laurel wreath in each upraised hand; the goddess figure stands on a base ornamented with bas-relief eagles. Four allegorical figures by Louis-Simon Boizot (1743-1809) ring the base of the fountain: Prudence, Temperance, Justice, and Strength. From top to bottom, bands of bronze gilt pay tribute to the victories achieved in the following battles: The Siege of Danzig (1807, Prussia), the Battle of Ulm (1805, Austria), the Battle of Marengo (1800, Italy), the Battle of the Pyramids (1798, Egypt), and the Battle of Lodi (1796, Italy). Its sphinxes were designed in 1858 by Gabriel Davioud and sculpted by Henri Alfred Jacquemart (1824-1896); they commemorate Napoleon's victory in Egypt.

photo.description: Elle doit son nom à la statue en plomb qui l'orne. Simon Boizot (1743 - 1809) la réalisa en 1807 pour la fontaine du Palmier, place du Châtelet. Elle représente une Victoire ailée dont les bras levés tiennent des couronnes de laurier en bronze. La statue qui surmonte actuellement la colonne de la fontaine est une copie. La statue du musée Carnavalet est donc l'original de la Victoire.

photo.description: Depuis les années 1990, un artiste français connu sous le pseudonyme d’Invader (aussi appelé Space Invader) envahit les villes du monde entier avec ses mosaïques, inspirées de Space Invaders et autres jeux vidéos de l'époque fin 1970 pré-1980. fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Invader_(artiste) Invader (born 1969) is a street artist who pastes up characters from and inspired by the Space Invaders game, made up of small coloured square tiles. He does this in cities across the world, then documents this as an "Invasion", with maps of where to find each invader. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Invader_(artist) site officiel / official website : www.space-invaders.com/

photo.description: La fontaine du Palmier ou de la Victoire, déplacée en 1855 sera rehaussée. Sa colonne est ornée de feuilles de palmiers. Elle est cerclée de bagues portant le nom des campagnes d'Egypte et d'Italie et surmontée d'un globe supportés par des nuages et de têtes d'anges. La Victoire tendant des couronnes de laurier, qui domine le monument, est une copie de l’œuvre de Boizot.
